div.l: Yf that I may · þe wenche here wolle I dyght
Some easement haþe þe lawe eshapen vs
For Iohan þer is a lawe · þat sayþe þus
Þat if a man in oon poynt been a grevid
Þat in a noþ̉er he shal beo relevid
Oure corne Is stolne sooþely þᵉʳ is noo nay
And we have hadde and eville fitte to daye
And sithen I shalle haue noon amendement
A geynst my losse I moste shape Easement
By goddis sowle it shalle non oth̉er beo
Þis Iohan answerd Aleyne / a vise þow þee
Þe miln̉er is a parelowse man he saide
And if þat he owte of his slepe abrayde
He myght þanne doon vs booþᵉ a vilany
Aleyne answerd I count him̄ nowte a pye
And vp he ryste ⁊and by þe wenche he crepte
Þis mayde laye vp Righte and faste eslepte
Til he so neyghe was / er sheo myght a spye
Þat hit had beo to late for to crye
But shortly for to sey / þey were at on̄
¶ Nowe pley Aleyne for I wolle speke of Iohn
Þis Iohan lyþe stylle a Furlong wey or two
And to him selfe / he makithe rowthe ⁊and woo
Ellas quod he þis is a wikked Iape
Nowe may I sayne / þat I is but an̄ ape
Yette hathe my Felawe somwhat For his harme
He hathe þe myllers dowt̉er in his arme
He aunterid him ⁊and hathe his his nedes spedde
And I lye as a draff sacke in my bedde
For whanne þis Iape · is told a noþir day
I shalle be holden a daffed nyse cokeney
I wolle aryse ⁊and aventure it by my feythe
Vnhardy vncelye loo þus men saithe
And vppe he Rosse ⁊and sofftlye forthe he went
Vn to the cradle / and in̄ his arms hit hent
And bare hit soffte vn̄ to his beddes Fete
¶ Soone afftir this the wyf her rowtyng leete
And ganne a wake and went her for to pisse
And came a geyne ⁊and ganne hir cradle for to misse
And gropid here ⁊and þer / but sheo fonde noon
Ellas quod sheo I hadde almoste mys I gon̄
Þus myght I have goon on̄ to þᵉ clerkes bedde
Eye benedicitee þanne hadde I fayre spedde
And Forthe sheo gooþe til sheo þᵉ cradle Fonde
Sheo gropeþe alweyes Further wᵗith hir honde
And Fond þᵉ bedde ⁊and demid noo thyng but good
By cause þᵗat þe cradle by his bedde stoode
And nyste wher sheo was for it was derke
But fayre ⁊and welle sheo crepte hir downe by þᵉ clerke
And lyeþe hir stille ⁊and wold have kavte a sleepe
Wᵗith Inne a whyle þis Iohan þᵉ clerke vppe lepe
And on̄ this good wyf he layþe on̄ soore
So mury a Fytte ne hadde sheo ful yeore
He prykeþᵉ harde and depe as he were madde
Þis Iolye lyffe have þes two clerkes hadde
Til that þe þrede Cook by gan to crowe
Aleyne wexsse wery by þat tyme I trowe
For he hadde swonken al þe long nyght
And saide fare wele Malyn̄ my swete wyght
Þe day Is commyn̄ I dare no leng̉er byde
But eủermore wher so I goo or Ryde
I am þin oune clerke so have I zele
Nowe dere lemman quod he goo fare wele
But or þowe goo / oon thyng I wolle þe telle
Whan þᵗat þowe weondeste homeward by þᵉ mille
Ryght at þᵉ Entree / of þe door͗e be hynde
Þowe shalt a Cake of half a busshell Fynd
Þᵗat was Emade nowe of þyne oune mele
Wiche þᵗat I helpe my Fadre For to stele
And goode lemman god þᵉ save ⁊and kepe
And withe þᵗat worde almoste sheo gan to wepe
¶ Aleyne vpperyste / and thoughte er þᵗat I dawe
I wolle goo creepen Inne be my felawe
And fonde þᵉ cradel wᵗith his hande a noon
By godde quod he al wrang have I mysgon̄
Myn̄ hede is toty of myn̄ swynke to nyght
Þat makeþᵉ me þᵗat I goo not aryght
I wate hit wele / þat I have al mys ga
He lyeþe þe miller ⁊and his wyf alswa
And foorþe he gooþe in twenty devilwaye
VnoVnoVn to the bedde þer as þe mylward laye
He wende have cropen downe by his felawe Iohn
And by þe myller þer he crepte a noon
And kaute him by þe necke and soffte he spake
He sayde howe þowe swyneshed awake
For crystes sowle and here a noble game
For by that lorde þᵗat callid is saynt Iame
As I have thryes in þis short nyght
Pleyed wᵗith þe mylners dowter bolt vp ryght
Wheyleste þow haste as a coward ben a gaste
Ye fals harlot quod þoo þoo þᵉ Milleward haste
A fals traytoᵘur ⁊and false cheorle quod he
Þow shalt beo dede be goddes dygnite
Whoo dovrste beo so bold to desparage
My dowter þᵗat is com of suche linage
And by þᵉ throte bolle he kavte Aleyne
And he hente him dispitowselye agayne
On nose and mowþᵉ he smote him wᵗith his fiste
Downe Ranne þᵉ blood vppon̄ his naked breste
And Inne þe floor͗e wᵗith nose ⁊and mowthe to broke
Þey walowen booþe as pigges don in a poke
And vppe they sterte and downe a gayne a noon
Til þᵗat þᵉ myln̉er spurnid at a stoone
And downe he felle backewardes vppon̄ his wyf
Þᵗat wist noo thyng of al þⁱˢ nyse stryffe
For sheo was falle on̄ slepe a litille wyght
Withe Iohan þᵉ Clerke þᵗat waked al þᵗat nyght
